descriptions: Teams net points while player is on the court.
Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description: Peja Stojakovic scored 32 points, including a pair of key late jumpers, as the Sacramento Kings posted a 110-98 victory over the Dallas Mavericks.
article.headline: Stojakovic's quick start buries Mavericks early

images.name: Stojakovic, Predrag 011129 inline
images.caption: Predrag Stojakovic scored 17 of his 32 points in the first quarter, when the Kings built a big lead.

article.linkText: Stojakovic takes care of business for Kings
article.story:
DALLAS (AP) -- Predrag Stojakovic got the Sacramento Kings started in the right direction, and then finished off the charging Dallas Mavericks at the end. Stojakovic scored 17 of his 32 points in the first quarter when Sacramento went ahead to stay. Then, after Dallas cut a 20-point deficit to four in the closing minutes, Stojakovic made his last three shots -- two with Steve Nash all over him -- leading the Kings to a 110-98 victory Thursday night. "He's just an unbelievable player. He came out real active, and the Mavs tried all kinds of different guys on him," Kings coach Rick Adelman said. "Give him credit, he just didn't settle for jumpers. He took the ball to the basket." The Kings, despite playing without injured All-Star forward Chris Webber (sprained left ankle), have the second-best record in the league at 12-4. Dallas (10-6) had its four-game winning streak snapped and was the 10th straight team that Sacramento held to less than 100 points. "We were on our heels all night trying to find some combination, something that worked," Mavs coach Don Nelson said. "They are very good and sometimes they can make you look bad." Stojakovic's 22-foot jumper with 2:40 left -- his first shot of the fourth quarter -- gave the Kings a 95-87 lead. Michael Finley then hit a 3-pointer from the corner at the other end, but Stojakovic came right back and shed Nash long enough for a fadeaway in the lane. "I'm supposed to take those shots when Chris isn't in there, and they felt good," said Stojakovic, who finished 13-of-19 from the field. "I felt good, kept shooting and my teammates were looking for me." The Mavericks, who overcame a 21-point deficit two nights earlier to beat Golden State, were down just 100-94 when Dirk Nowitzki scored with 1:18 left. But Stojakovic did it again, hitting another tough 15-foot jumper over Nash to seal the game. After playing at San Antonio on Friday, Sacramento returns home for five games in eight days. That stretch includes a Dec. 7 game against the Pacific Division-leading Los Angeles Lakers (13-1). Stojakovic was 7-of-8 shooting with two 3-pointers in the first quarter, when the Kings built a 30-23 lead. Sacramento never trailed after his jumper made it 12-11, and he converted a three-point play on the next possession after a steal by Doug Christie. "He started lighting it up," Mavericks forward Juwan Howard said. "One time, I was all in his face and he shot it so deep. We knew we were in for a long night." The Kings led 59-41 at halftime, but the Mavericks cut the lead under double-digits when Tim Hardaway hit back-to-back 3-pointers to make it 72-64 with three minutes left in the third quarter. Hardaway finished with 16 points. "The second half, you know that team is going to make a run at you," Adelman said. "We talked about their ability to come back on you. But we sustained it and made our one little run at the end." Hedo Turkoglu had 17 points in a reserve role for Sacramento, while Bobby Jackson had 16. Scot Pollard had 17 rebounds, including consecutive tip-in baskets in the second quarter. Nowitzki scored the first five points of the game and finished with 29, just missing his fourth straight 30-point game. He also had 11 rebounds. Finley had 21 points.

Game notes
The Mavericks missed their 10th November win, which would have been a franchise record. Dallas was 9-6, its eight straight winning month, dating back to April 2000. ... Finley extended his NBA-best streak of active games played to 476, while Sacramento's Mike Bibby played in his 230th straight, which ranks fifth. On the active consecutive starts list, Finley is second with 346 -- 30 behind Milwaukee's Ray Allen -- and Bibby is fourth at 230. ... Adelman is five victories shy of becoming the 22nd NBA coach to win 500. ... The Kings lead the series against Dallas 52-49. The two teams play again Sunday in Sacramento.

statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).
